article_title: Busting myths and delivering facts about getting vaccinations
article_text:
Busting myths and delivering facts about getting vaccinations

Photo: -- Each gym has its own etiquette and its own culture, said Rosemary...

Measles is making a comeback, with a 20-year high in reported infections, due mostly to folks who are opting out of the vaccination, says the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Across the nation, an epidemic of whooping cough in California, outbreaks of chickenpox in Indiana and measles in Ohio have made national headlines.

article_metadata.description: Measles is making a comeback, with a 20-year high in reported infections, due mostly to folks who are opting out of the vaccination, says the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.  Across the nation, an epidemic of whooping cough in California, outbreaks of chickenpox in Indiana and measles in Ohio have made national headlines.  In many cases, the anti-vaccine movement is persuading parents not to vaccinate their children; that's causing a lot of harm to at-risk children and adults who are susceptible to these preventable diseases.  During a pre-vaccine rubella (German measles) outbreak in the 1960s, 2,000 babies died and 11,000 pregnant women had miscarriages.  Infants receive their first of two measles vaccinations between 12-15 months and their first of four pertussis inoculation shots starting at 2 months; until those kick in, they are at risk for infection, when these diseases can be most dangerous.  About 40 percent of people age 65 and older haven't received a pneumonia vaccine, and 85 percent are missing out on the shingles vaccine, which protects against excruciating nerve pain.  A whopping 86 percent of adults haven't had their Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis) booster (recommended every 10 years), and 87 percent haven't had a hepatitis A booster, while 65 percent skip the hepatitis B vaccine.  Plenty of teens and young adults are missing out on the meningococcal vaccine (plus a booster shot), which can prevent 80 percent of meningitis cases (a potentially fatal bacterial infection), and about 65 percent of young women and 95 percent of young men ages 19-26 haven't gotten the HPV vaccine, proven to slash risk for infections that cause many cases of throat cancer and most cervical cancer.  Physical activity in the morning helps reduce blood pressure during the day and boosts brain power (cognitive function and mental acuity) for four to 10 hours.
